result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.
result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Jeremy S. Bruce

records.addlTxt:
Conditions: 
No contact with anyone involved in illegal drug activities, except in a therapeutic setting. 
Defendant to maintain absolute sobriety. 
Defendant not to consume/possess any alcohol or go into any taverns, bars, liquor stores/place where alcohol is primarily served/sold. 
Comply with Pre-Trial Monitoring Services with possible testing based on monitoring level in conjunction with CTC.
(Covers 22CF1153, 21CF1333).

Cases called at 11:08 AM: 21CF1333, 22CF1153.
Defendant Jeremy S. Bruce appeared by video, in custody from the jail with Attorney Sonia Anderson.  Prosecuting Attorney Monica A Fallon in court for the State of Wisconsin. 
21CF1333: Warrant quashed. State requests $100 Cash Bond to cover both cases. Court so orders. Time limits for preliminary hearing waived in both cases.
Defendant is not eligible for Public Defender representation. 
Settlement Conference (by phone) with District Attorney's Office (715-839-4828) on 11/7/22 at 3:00 PM.
